comment: First and foremost, this is nutty and medicinal, with a pretty strong overlay of seaweed, toffee, and...is that...fish oil? The aftertaste has that kind of numbing, witch hazel hum that will remind you of your earliest experience with cheap brown liquor. Listen, I prefer single malts that have an attitude, that make a statement, that shriek "I am here, dammit!", and this spirit does that. Do I wish there was more peat, maybe more cherry or vanilla (as opposed to that toffee/nougat thing!) and less of the rubbing alcohol-like numbing anti-taste? Why, yes I do. Yet the Laphroaig 10 says, I AM IN YOUR MOUTH, PAY ATTENTION, and I like that. And this is probably why I rate this as high as I do.
Best scotch ever for $50. Be adventurous.

I am a new taster so take my notes with a grain of salt. I tasted sea salt immediately, followed by heavy peat smoke. This is a drink I will not forget but it is a flavor that is very specific. Do not plan on drinking anything after this. I had the flavor on my palette for the rest of the night.

The heavy fusel burn dovetails perfectly with the peat smoke. All the usual descriptors: smoked meat, campfire, tobacco ash, cigars. It's all cliche but it's because it's all true.

It does benefit from a droplet, only because the moss and soil then overshadows the alcohol heat. It's the most boggy whiskey that I've had with the possible exception of Ardbeg 10.
I getting the feeling a bog fire punches you in the mouth with every sip, but you’re not unhappy about it. Notes of smoke, honey, salt, and maybe fish oil?
Amazingly smoky! Work bonfire and bandaid notes
This is on the money for me every time.  If there was a perfect scotch for me at this price point this would be it.  Super smokey.
Lots of character. Aftertaste is more of an antiseptic and bandaid flavor.

(Edit: I am tasting the 43%) Initial peat is very present. Definitely one of the more peaty whiskeys. The peat consists of bandaid rubber, medicinal notes, and meat that has been charred black. Also has a brine of seawater, reminds me of washed up kelp almost. Behind that there is a classic malty sweetness. The back end sweetness is actually very floral and pretty

If Ardbeg 10 takes you into battle and enhances confidence, this is the one you drink the next day as you are appreciating your victory.  It’s subtle and has a lot more under the smoke.  Just wish the smoke was a little lighter so the rest was easier to find.  But it’s there if you look close enough.  Takes you to a cold windy beach.  

Smokey, ash, salt water, grass tasting notes, campfire nose.

Absolutely, a great sipping whisky.  The strong peaty, smoky first sniff just mellows out with each subsequent nip.  I'm not a guzzler.....have recently recognized the indescribable attractiveness of an extended visit with a dram of good Scotch.  Bucket list entry:  visit Islay and tour as many distilleries as possible!  Thanks Scotland!
Ocean briney nose, salt, smoke. Smooth medicinal iodine.
Always a win. Peaty for peat lovers. Band-aids and bonfires
Whew! Peaty as predicted...free bottle’s a free bottle though 🥴

My 2nd taste of a peated whiskey. It went a little better than the first taste I had but I’m still not a huge fan of a peated scotch. Although it got better on ice. I have a tough time drinking something that tastes like medicines, before they figured out how to flavor them, not that flavored meds are much better, unless it’s kids medicine LOL. I’ll pass on the band aid flavored scotches thank you :-).
Unbeatable for the money. A peaty whiskey status symbol
Whoa - that is rich, smokey, charted peat. Not as sweet as Johnnie Walker black, way smokier. Eventually, get spicy vanilla and a little cinnamon.

Initially all I could taste and smell was smoke. I did a dilution on the side and let that sit on the tongue for a bit to try and pick up some other flavors. I was able to pick up some vanilla. Going back to straight laphroiag, I was then able to pick up some sweeter notes, followed by some sour/tartness. Surprisingly no heat-definitely would try again when I’m in the mood for something smokey.
Smokey, peaty, slight sweetness. Briney finish
beautiful finish with long lasting vanilla and smokey finish

Tasted neat and it was a bit harsh. Once I put a rock in it I was able to appreciate the strong peat up front followed by a complex finish. Lots of lingering flavor but not bad at all. This is something I would add to my collection for occasional drinking or for guests who appreciate peaty scotch more than I do. Thanks For the introduction @hennynme
Very peaty and smooth for a 10 year.  Little less refined the Laguvulin 16

4.75. Just absolutely love this whisky. Peat smoke and brine on nose. Smoky finish. I do catch the “band-aid” a little. Nice to sip in the evening to relax. Like a warm blanket next to a campfire on a brisk night.

I love a good challenge from a whiskey and Laphroaig is always a good challenge with hints of seawater and rubber, lending itself to a smoky finish that’s hard to shake. May not be my favorite Islay but it’s fantastic for what it is.

Very oily. Almost thick. The smokiness is more on nose than palate. The finish is very long. I do prefer the Triple wood edition because I like the woody taste, but this is a reliable scotch if you want Islay
I worked quite a while to taste other qualities past the deep heavy smoke and never succeeded. Good for a pour for sure, will return after my peat journey and give it another go.
Very nice peat flavor, not too strong. Adding water brought out more of the vanilla flavor. The saltyness in the sea air is evident.

Rich, strong tasting, with really interesting notes, not only overwhelming peat, but seaweed, iodine, salt, fruits behind the initial notes listed. This combination of tastes creates one whisky you can never forget.
Heavy smokey, but clean, flavor with a bit of a toffee and vanilla finish

My first foray into peat, was definitely afraid since people I knew called it the palate killer.

Nose: salty, briny, smoked jerky, after exhausting my nose to those smells, I get some sort of fruit zest and vanilla

Taste: Smokey, salty, charred meat, light sweetness on end

Finish: there’s a subtle heat, like embers in a fireplace that just sit there. Feel like all parts of my mouth are being triggered. Not localized to one area. Long Finish. Still present after much time.
Tastes like it fermented on the forest floor after a forest fire

Color: Orange and yellow almost golden
Smell: Smoke and vanilla
Taste: Peaty and sweet 
Aftertaste: Smoky taste lags behind and some dryness

Laphroaig 10. I've reviewed so many bottlings from this distillery, and somehow am just getting around to reviewing its staple product. The first peated whisky I had ever owned. Or tasted for that matter. And I absolutely hated it. I actually thought it was expired. Slowly, it grew on me. And the rest...

Nose: Classic Laphroaig notes. Seaweed, sea salt, brine, iodine, and band-aid. Peat and campfire smoke. Black pepper and oak. Ash and charcoal, grapefruit and lemon citrus. Smoked meats, rib, and brisket. A bit of custard and vanilla sweetness, maybe even mint chocolate. Some of the classic Laphroaig chestnut note, though it disappears after about 10 minutes. But brine, smoke, peat, meat, oak, medicinal notes, and citrus dominate here. Very complex for 43% ABV.

Palate: Campfire smoke, ash, charcoal, and peat take the forefront. Brine, salt, seaweed, iodine, and band-aid remain. Surprisingly, I'm getting strong fruit notes: the lemon is still there, but takes a back seat to apple, pear, peach, and apricot. Still getting the meat notes, as well as the vanilla. Some dark chocolate appears with time in the glass. The custard is gone, and it's a bit thinner than the nose let on. Still getting oak and black pepper, now with cinnamon. Very good.

Finish: Medium-long. Heaps of charcoal, ash, smoke, and sea salt. Dark chocolate carries over, even stronger than on the palate. Then it's black pepper, cinnamon, and oak. The spice also presents as a red-pepper e chili here. Impressive finish, especially considering the proof.

And there it is. The fact that I now enjoy this stuff, which I once considered undrinkable, is a landmark in my whisky journey. I've enjoyed this for years at this point, but this is the first time I've put those thoughts to pen and paper, if you will.

This is one of my defaults at bars. It's very common, which means I've almost always got a top-notch pour available. This is one of the great flagship products in all of the whisky world. Worth the time of experienced peat heads and beginners alike. And it's easily one of the best VFM purchases one could make. Nothing but good things to say about this one. If you haven't tried it yet, and can handle a bit of peat, make buying this one a priority.

This is an excellent choice for Scotch lovers looking for a steal in terms of value. Where most "cheap" options would probably lead you to something like a Johnny Walker or lower end Balvenie, Laphroaig 10 doesn't compromise quality while still remaining more than affordable. It's remarkably peaty and finishes smooth. Definitely one to keep in the cabinet.

I think I’m in the minority with this one.  I find I like the cask strength stuff from laphroaig much better.  While it’s plenty smoky with that BBQ seaweed flavor I like,  I still think the cask strength 10 year is a complete step above

I think I’m in the minority with this one.  I find I like the cask strength stuff from laphroaig much better.  While it’s plenty smoky with that BBQ seaweed flavor I like,  I still think the cask strength 10 year is a complete step above

Peat, smoke, green apple/pear, vanilla 

Bitter/ tannic aftertaste

smoky, pitty, cool, light,
sharp, 
may be good with beef.

"fine and tough master"

If you love Peaty scotch then this is the one! The first initial taste just lights you up like a cold night by the Christmas tree... whatever that means lol. It has this slight wood taste that will put some hair in your chest. Goes great with a steak too. The smell is a deep smoked wood with a pinch of cherry, gives you a feeling of being a log cabin. Highly recommend my dude or dudette
Iodine and smokey but a surprising amount of melon and a touch of green apple. Long lingering finish.
Smokey, with a charcoal taste. Slightly sweet and a synthetic rubber nose

Really nice peaty  smokey ad sweet
Not too complex
Solid drink
One of my favs,  lots of smoke memories of smoked moose hide.  And a nice mouth feel full with a sweet vanillan finish

Burn on the nose

Sweet on the first taste

Bacon, peat smoke, rubber on the swallow

Smooth finish, fruity vanilla sweetness

(2/20/20)
Taste like a burnt lawn on a southern Saturday night.
You can taste the wood and the smoke.
Typical peaty notes. Smooth finish. This is an everyday pour. Do yourself a favor and go get a bottle or two.

Smoke, mossy peat, tobacco leaf, earthy potting soil, gasoline fusels that somehow work.

Mildly salty; definitely plastic/phenolic stuff at the back end: rubber bands.

There is nothing quite like Laphroaig.
Very smokey as expected, quite mellow and a little bit woody?
Interesting, but very peaty. Hard to drink more than one glass of.

Nose: ash, smoke, fish/fish sauce, licorice/sweet

Taste: strong wood and smoke

First islay whiskey ive tasted, people always told me that islay whiskeys are more of an acquired taste and more for advance whiskey drinkers
Well i absolutely loved it from the first sip!
Taste like licking wood from a bonfire
With some sweetness and hinch of saltines

Smelled seaweed for sure, and perhaps salt and hickory. Tasted seaweed, lightly smoked ham, mildly earthy and definitely briny. Just the right amount of peat. I loved and love it. Best bang for the buck.

Last dram of the bottle

Nose: lemon pledge cleaner and ashtray
Taste: citrus fruit, iodine, burnt rubber
Finish: medium peat finish - not as "peat flash-back" inducing as Ardbeg 10

Value: Good, not great whisky. Glad I tried a whole bottle, but probably wouldn't buy again...too many other wonderful whiskys to try.
A camp fire in my mouth, and that’s a good thing! If you enjoy peat you will enjoy this.

Iodine and medicinal. Reminds me of the throat coat spray. Bright and Smoky. Salty, brine. A sort of sweet malt finish that lingers. A slight leather note? 
Really delicious.

2nd tasting 2020, the watered down 40% version. Peaty, smoky, of course, medicinal, got to love that. Fisherman's friend, liquorice, seaside, seaweed, some grass, spruce, but this time it feels processed, not as fresh as Ardbeg. Added color? Filtered? This could be one of the best. It is good, it is awesome, but next time I will try PX or Lore. This particular whisky is a favourite one day and the next it is not. Just live with it.

It had it's good points, but was a let down for a first impression of the distillery. There was plenty of peat, but many of the subtler smells were covered up by a burnt rubber smell. The taste had it's good points, but the finish was like wet paper. I ended up mixing it with Bushmills to balance out the sour notes. I'd be willing to give it another chance because it's Laphroaig. I've heard that older batches were better. Maybe I was just unlucky, but for the price point, Ardbeg 10 is unbeaten.

Nose: big briny medicinal peat with orchard fruits in the background. 

Taste: peat like liquid electricity, wood smoke, with notes of soggy cut grass, old leather, green apple, lavender, and wintergreen mint.

A classic must-try.
Like drinking a mermaids bathwater. Truly amazing
Smoke! Salty sweet ocean, bbq, black pepper.

This tastes about how you’d expect. Like a campfire struggling to stay lit on a rainy, windswept beach - all that stuff. But what surprised me was the malt flavor. It kinda reminds me of a graham cracker, or a fancy tea biscuit. Quite nice, and no off-flavors (if you’re into this sort of thing).
Smoke with sweet notes underneath it.
Wow, what a nose. Something's burnt to a crisp. Strong palate. Many nuances. Sniffing it over and over reveals a sweetness and seaweed/oysters/citrus. Even a whiff of caramel.

One of my go to peated Scotches. Delivers enough smokey, salty goodness with lovely notes and aromas of vanilla, soft citrus, butterscotch and toast to really drove it home. Also, for a scotch of its pedigree and age, affordable (sort of). Recommended for those really ready to dig into Scotchs more peaty offerings.

N:  peat, smoke, seashore, bacon
P:  smoke, bacon
F:  

Coach Grill, Wayland, MA

Like licking the old coals of a campfire after throwing a piece of BBQ into it. 

Not a peat guy yet but I’m getting to where I can appreciate it!
Nose: campfire, salt air, peat, malt, tobacco Palate: campfire, salt air, peat malt, tobacco, spice Finish: lasting smoke taste with spice note that fades quickly
Smooth with a very smoky finish

Compact nose shows sea breeze, petrol, butterscotch, and just a little smoke.  The palate is where the peat explodes.  To me, the Laphroaig 10 is like the inverse of the Lagavulin 16: the Lagavulin is heavy up front with peat but then dials it back in favor of other flavors, where the Laphroaig holds the peat back and then suddenly smacks you in the mouth with it.  It’s not overwhelming, though.  Saltwater, mint, generic melon, and new tires turn up in the mouth, too.  The lingering burn makes it seem like higher than 43% ABV, and in the best possible way.  It’s full, oily, and multidimensional, with a long weedy finish.  Hard to ask for anything more at this price.
Very solid. I get a bit of a linger but I like the Smokey balanced taste.
Smoke smoke smoke! That's your first impression but wait...there's more! Worth every penny
Smokey but sweet! Has a very peat and seaweed like flavor. The sweetness I taste is like mango’s and a bittersweet chocolate.

A smoke bomb... but for peat lovers... a bargain.  Tasty and smooth... but a bit much.

IMHO... there are many peated single malts that are more subtle... and superior.  A "96" is pushing it.
Like someone put a cigarette out in your mouth. In a good way!
Exceptional peat & fruit. Oily, with a vanilla/band-aid finish.
You really get a experience with each sip of this scotch. You get smoked peat heavily up front with a very light vanilla after taste. There’s almost a light coffee finish.
If there’s a “crushable” Laphroaig, this is it. So easy. Vanilla and honey on the nose carries to a sweet palate followed by med- campfire, medicinal, slight seaweed. Short finish.
Very medicinal, old bandages soaked in iodine... thin body with sweetness on the finish...
Une tourbe présente, entourée de notes végétales, terreuses
Really like this scotch. Love the peat, smoke, and that seaweed. Very good for the price ($69CAD). Can handle some water.

Peated with a slightly medicinal or iodine note.



My Rating Glossary:  

Two Stars:           "I'd rather be drinking lite beer."
Two 1/2 Stars:    "Posh rubbish."
Three Stars:        "I love whisk(e)y.  This is average love."
Three 1/2 Stars: "May buy again."
Four Stars:          "I've got to get you into my life."
Four 1/2 Stars:   "Better than drugs."
Five Stars:           "Life is good.  Whisky makes it better."
Very peaty and smokey but nicely balanced.
Everybody needs to have a bottle of Laphroaig!

My ‘go to’ dram, Laphroaig 10y/o always has a place at the front of my cabinet.

Upfront it’s medicinal, TCP and seaweed.  Surprisingly sweet, with a good amount of oak, black pepper and chilli.  The finish mellows it out into the charred wood and seaweed as it lingers on the aftertaste.

If you like an Islay, this is a great all rounder - a warm welcome in a glass.
Mixed feelings. The thing the smoky notes remind me of is smoked bacon (by no means meant to disrespect this whiskey). As a beginner, I feel slightly overwhelmed by this. Will get back to it!
Saltwater, fresh-cut grass, peaches, apples, loam
Wakes you and all your sense up, peat to the max and small tinge of vanilla
Smoke and Peaty. Outstanding as always.

A friend of mine: It smells and tastes like burnt rubber!
Me: I know, isn't it great???

A different friend: It's like smoke and really, really iodine-ey!
Me: I know!!!!
Great for just having around. Great all around scotch
Peat, and some more peat. Smooth and simple. Great Scotch.
Medicine. I'm a beginner whiskey drinker, however.

F-I-N-A-L-L-Y. I have finally found the legendary whisky that once opened, the bottle smells like a fresh can of recently opened tennis balls. The myth is true, this is the one. Not on the glass though, it has this note in the bottle.

After that exciting event, i got to say that Laphroaig 10 year old is a heavily peated, very "islay" dram. As a fact i have tasted (and loved) the Johnnie Walker Island Green, and now i know what does it have inside: its laphroaig.

On the nose, once the bottle is opened, if you smell it, you will percieve a freshly opened can of tennis balls. On the glass it is a typical Islay single malt: very peated, prunes and bonfire. Lovely.

On the palate is medium-long bodied with a very straightforward note of burnt rubber or burnt meat, that instantly changes into a hot (mild) and spicy (pleasant) note.  Finish is medium, with hints of mint and spices. 

The whole experience is awesome, you should try this at least once just to teach yourself and others that not every whisky is alike. If you pick any highland whisky, this is the complete opposite. Beautiful, drink it on a beach day
The best scotch for the price out there in my opinion, especially if you like Islas. Very smoky but super flavorful and very enjoyable to drink. I love this scotch
Smooth and rich with an extremely smoky finish
Coming from a bourbon fan, I do like this whiskey. I can't get through the peaty smokiness yet, to unveil those sweet notes. But I enjoy the smokiness and barbecue flavors, sulfur/asphalt
Blommig som en äng, rökig som en kolgrill
Easily a top 5 scotch for me. Smoky, iodiney, delightful
Very peaty. A little glass of smoke

My first Islay, but somehow the scent and flavours seem so familiar. Like when in my life have I been in an old shoemakers shop chewing on his latest works while a fire has started in the middle of the room?
Nose is intense. Smokey, medicinal, earthy, kinda funky. The taste is pretty much identical. The finish lingers forEVER. Really interesting overall.
Salty and peaty on the nose. Vanilla and peat smoke similar to smoked ribs. Lingering and persistent finish. Great Islay whisky.
Good but their Triple Wood is much, much better

One of my favorite scotches. It’s extremely peaty, but very well-balanced, which makes for a very smooth dink. The nose is peat, which carries on to the first taste, along with some sweetness. It has a medium finish, but because it is so smooth, there is very little bite. At the typical price point, Laphroaig 10 is hard to beat.
Full of character. Rich smokey, peaty flavour. Long lasting finish
The best value Islay and it is just fantastic.  The standard bottling is a must have.
Not as thick as the Ardbeg but smoke is nice

Nose: BBQ, Salt water, Smoky, floral, slight medicinal, caramel, butterscotch 

Pallet: Smoky, Cigar, salty, savory, seaweed, medicinal, BBQ, brisket

Finish: Medicinal, smoke, cigar

Grade: 85/100

Very unique smell compared to what I’m used too.  I’m fairly new to scotch, especially high end.  Bourbon is usually my first choice but scotch is definitely growing on me.  At first it smells like chloraseptic spray bit as you sniff deeper you can smell the smoky peat, very refreshing.  
Once you taste it, that numbing tingly feel takes effect but it also sends a warm shot through your body.  Overall it’s different from anything I’ve ever tasted but I’m definitely a fan.  Warning: it could be an acquired taste for some.
Getting a lot of vanilla on the nose tonight, seems to even overtake the peat smoke. Still has the same great taste we’ve all come to love. Smoke, brine, and medicinal notes...
Almost as good as Lagavulin. Love the smokey flavor. One the best.
Clearly peated, but nice and sea-salty with some floral notes once you get past the smoke. Dense but not heavy
Solid peaty drink without the price tag gilt. One of the best all arounder with a sense of exclusiveness. Great value if you are looking for a peaty drink.
Smoke and bright fruit notes bandaids

Peaty smoke, seaweed and salt. My first Islay and I’m hooked, despite the aroma being unusual for a novice like myself. Very smooth with a gentle finish. Reminiscent of an evening campfire on a cold seashore of the north.
P. E. A. T. I felt like the guy who had the campfire smoke chase me all night.
Caramel colour. Peaty sweet nose vanilla. Smoky, savoury, seaweed, medicinal

Nose: seaweed, quite gentle...
Taste: seaweed, medicinal but not too much... 
aftertaste: burn,
Smoky, bitter. I can smell a sea in it.

I’m just getting into whisky and don’t know how to find all the notes that I hear others finding so take this for what it’s worth; an amateur’s opinion.

The nose for me is all smoke, with a permanent marker type of vibe mixed with cough syrup, but I a good way (if that makes any sense).

The taste up front is heavy smoke that rolls into a woody/earthy tone midway. The finish is a faint sweetness (somewhere along the lines of caramel)

So far Laphroiag 10 and Ardbeg 10 are the only whiskies I can truly say I enjoy neat.
A great whisky, but too peaty for my tastes.

Get ready for the peat! But there is so much character and body beyond that. The salt, the brine, the smoke, the salt, the vanilla. It's like smelling an old bonfire on a beach in Oregon. If you've never been to the Pacific Northwest, then you'll really never understand the flavor profile because it really does taste like you're standing 10 feet from the ocean. It's wonderful.
Smoky peat, medicinal, salty seaweed-oddly delicious!
Smoky with a nice sweetness to it!
Classic laphroaig camp fire smoke. Not overpowering, and extremely enjoyable. Noticeable peat, hints of brine, notes of leather, pepper, and bacon fat.
Yes, of course the peatiness is the main feature here, but I was actually impressed with the relative complexity of this - there’s a great honey taste and notes of sea salt and licorice as well.
The more I drink it, the more I love it.  That, or my tastebuds are committing mass tastecide.

"Lost in a storm at sea while your galleon is burning " 

Smoky, salty a touch medicinal this was the beginning of the Islay for me. Absolutely delicious.
Brine, smoke, and sweetness.  Has that medicinal note to it with a minty finish. Not as complex as Lagavulin 16 or as meaty as Ardbeg 10 but a smooth, easy drinking dram.

Nose: initial delicious briny nose that leads to a full and floral body. The peat that makes it so enticing floats around that whole aroma. The more it airs out the more I get if a bitterness akin to dark chocolate without the sweetness to follow. 

Taste: Beautiful, full mouth feel that coats my tongue. It starts out very light, most likely the alcohol vapors filling my mouth up then moves to something smoky. Also the quickest most delightful heat right before it just hangs out on the tongue.  Flavors for me included something herbal yet savory, maybe like a cinnamon without the spice. Couldn’t quite place it. 

Overall: 4 stars. Love Islay scotch and Laphroaig is one of my favorites after the Quarter Cask. Would definitely recommend, but not for the tame.
Nose: smoke. A lot. Taste: salty, burnt Wood with a crisp bonfire taste as finish
bit too peaty for my taste
I guess this is essentially islay in a bottle.

Nose is not as powerful as I thought it would be. 
On the palate is indeed very medicinal, and Briny, sea, etc... But not as smoky as I thought it would be. 
I do get the fact it is 10 years old only but I find it think on the palate. 
I'd still prefer a Lag over this.

Nose
Fire smoke peat, nutty, grain, salt

Palate
Smokey peat, salt, grain, citrus
Smoke, apple, cinnamon, would need to build up towards enjoying the peat
Not bad, gotta try the cask strength sometime. Smokey and peaty but pretty smooth overall.

Nose: smoldering campfire on a beach, iodine, hint floral note, chocolate. On third sip, seaweed like nori, then tar?
Palate: salt, black pepper, iodine/medicinal, incense. A meaty savoriness.
Finish: long oily, mostly peat smoke and brine, hint of something sweet - maybe like a dark honey.
Smoke, peat, phenol, tar, malt, savory mouthfeel.
The bottle that introduced me to peat.

It’s like swallowing a campfire whole and not getting burned by the flames. On the tongue, I pick up a small hint of formaldehyde, or at least that’s what the fumes of Dr. Muhammad’s A&P class all those years ago led me to believe it would taste like. Weird, right? What’s weirder is my taste buds welcomed it. A good slap in the face for when you’ve been a real naughty boy.

This is the marmite of Whisky. You either love it or hate it. I love it. Absolutely love this. Think a clinical, hospital environment on the nose, maybe some plasters and iodine. Then the power of the sea is in the background but keep on the nose and I find creamy toffee notes and salted caramel. A real dirty peat which Laphroaig is famed for, unlike some other sweet peats that can come from Islay. 
If I’m having a couple of drams, I sometimes like to start with the laphraoig 10 before going for something sweet afterwards. It completely opens your inner sense of smell and taste. 
Delightful! 🥃
Wtf are the experts thinking with this one... taste like a tin of grizzly mixed with an air freshener
I’m pretty sure that this is not safe to drink. It would have been cheaper to pick up some iodine from the local pharmacy, pour on ice, and garnish with a dirty band-aid from the trash can
Killing the last of my bottle. Hard to come back to this after the QC haha
Nearly perfect whiskey for the price

Nose: Peat! As expected, of course. Absolutely delightful blend of smokey and oaky. Smells of the seaside, pleasantly salty.

Palate: Sweeter than the nose with some hints of vanilla and cane sugar. Saltiness and smokiness blending together. Some very light malty notes as well.

Finish: Long and smokey. Very gentle and subtlety salty. Feels like the end of a nice beach day. 

Overall Thoughts: This is one of my absolute favorite Scotch whiskies in the world. It’s one I’ve gifted for very special occasions and one I always recommend to newbies and one I love to enjoy with my whisky-drinking friends. Laphroaig truly is a rich and special whisky.

Was my first peated Islay whiskey so for me the peat was overpowering but pleasent. Im told if you’ve been around the block a few times this malt falls into to the lighter-brighter category of peaty malts. 
So, the nose is strong on peat, iodine-saltiness, seaweed and some kind of fresh medicinal smell. It smell like as if you have just put out a campfire made on the beach with seawater that had seaweed in it.

The taste is very similiar to the nose, however it is suprisingly sweet. That medicinal sweetness is much brighter than you would think from the nose.
I cant quite recognize what kind of sweetness that is, maybe some lemony-sugary.

On the finish, the salty seaweed and peat stays for a very long time. I have felt them in my mouth after half on our of drinking the last sip, even after having 3 scoops of ice cream.
Very nice introduction to strong Islay flavors. I liked it, however i would not have it as a daily drinker just yet.
It’s ridiculously balanced for Islay Scotch. Not too peaty yet not too sweet.

Nose: smoke from embers, green apple, iodine, cocoa powder, faint hemlock. 
Palate: sweet - very mild and fleeting (like a piece of grilled pineapple) , black pepper - iodine. Hint of smoked meat - short in duration.
Finish: slightly oily, mild peat smoke. slight sweetness - very short ending with slight iodine.
Full flavoured. Long finish. Have tried many but always back to this
Excellent evening dram.  A smooth, rich, peat-forward whisky that rounds off a good day...and somehow makes it better.  My go-to everyday scotch

Laphroaig 10YO 43%
Much more bitter than the usual. More medicine 
2.25
Sweet and salty with an upfront and lingering smokey taste.

And yet I return to you, old friend. Like that Drifters song Save the Last for Me. I may flirt with others. I may even enjoy the exciting novelty of their company. But at the end of the night, I go home with you.
It’s growing on me. Certainly deep and complex.

So I have heard a lot about this whisky and really wanted to expand my scotch pallet. I went to a local establishment and asked for a Laphroaig 10 thinking I'd get a 1 oz neat..i receive about a 3oz amount of this........and then the results

Im only giving this a 2 because I enjoy the smoke. Everything else you hear and see of this tasting and smelling like band aids and hospitals and seaweed is SPOT on. I don't honestly know why anyone would want to drink band aid but if that's you..go for it!
Not usually a scotch fan but damn this was tasty
